container-title: Subsequently, Averroes (520/1126–595/1198) adopted the term ṭarīq in the west. When Averroes was translated into Latin, the term ṭarīq was rendered as via, not methodos, so that his follower, Thomas Aquinas (1225–1274), wrote about the five viae for proving the existence of God. title: Greek philosophers first coined the term ‘method
A Greek-English Lexicon
following after, pursuit, method’]). Their Roman disciples incorporated this term into Latin as methodos

The Latin form of this word is first documented in Vitruvius Pollio (De Architectura), who flourished in the age of Augustus (r. 63 BC–AD 14). Much later, the Arabs retranslated this Greek term, literally, as ṭarīq, ṭarīqa (‘road, path, way’), and used it in philosophical discourse. Thus, in the east, Avicenna (370/980–428/1037) employed the term. For his heavy reliance on Aristotelian terminology, see, Amélie-Marie Goichon, Lexique de la langue philosophique d’Ibn Sīnā (Avicenne): Vocabulaires comparés dʾAristote et d’Ibn Sīnā
